root.publications: Grierson, George A. 1963. General Results of the Survey, Linguistic Survey of India, vol. 1. Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass.
root.pub-comments: The Linguistic Survey of India (LSI) is a historically significant attempt to document the languages spoken in what was then British India and nearby areas. Reproduced here is the classification of the Aryan Languages (approximately corresponding to modern scholars' "Indo-Iranian Languages") from that Survey. We have also digitized many maps from the LSI in our LL-MAP project (llmap.org), to which this tree is intended to act as a companion; please search "Linguistic Survey of India" in LL-MAP to find these. Finally, the original text of the LSI is publicly available in searchable form at http://joao-roiz.jp/LSI/ - thanks go to Masayuki Toyoshima (豊島正之) for maintaining this page.

child.pub-comments: Grierson believes there should be something equivalent to Proto Eranian, from which the modern branches of Eranian and Dardic developed, but he does not give this a name (1903: 100).

child.alt-names: Piśācha Sub-family, Pisacha Sub-family, Dardic Family, Dardic Sub-family
child.pub-comments: Though Grierson sometimes refers to a "Dardic Family", he is not using the word "family" in the modern sense of the word (to denote a group of languages conclusively related to one another but not to others), since he clearly indicates that Eranian, Indo-Aryan, and Dardic are all branches of an Aryan family.

child.pub-comments: "The word 'Dard' properly belongs to the tribes immediately to the north of Kashmir, but has in modern times been extended to include all the inhabitants of Dardistan. I have followed this by giving the term 'Dardic' to all the languages of Dardistan, while I reserve 'Dard' for its proper use as indicating the group of languages of eastern Dardistan, viz., Shiṇā, Kāshmīrī, and Kōhistānī" (Grierson 1903:112).

child.pub-comments: The Linguistic Survey of India's Dardic Languages map shows Veron and not Presun; the accompanying text lists Presun and not Veron. The Indo-European composite tree in Multitree lists these two as alternate names for the same language, so I have assumed they are meant to refer to the same language here, and represent an internal inconsistency of the LSI.

child.pub-comments: Rōshanī is mentioned nowhere in Grierson's text, but is clearly marked on the accompanying map. Because it is only found on the map, there is no indication as to whether Grierson means it to be its own language, or a dialect of some other language. However, he states that Shighnī is spoken in Shighnān and Rōshān (Grierson 1903:466); the common naming convention for Indian languages (place name plus -ī suffix) would therefore imply that Rōshānī is the variety of Shighnī spoken in Rōshān, plus Rōshānī has a dialect code under Shighni in the MultiTree database. Based on these two pieces of evidence, I have placed it as a dialect of Shighnī in this tree.

He simply mentions them to differentiate them from the Medic or Non-Persic languages.

child.alt-names: Lahnda, Western Panjabi, Western Pañjābī, Jaṭkī, Mūltānī, Hindkī, Hindkō
child.pub-comments: "Lahndā… has long been recognised under various names such as Jaṭkī, Mūltānī, Hindkī or Hindkō, and Western Pañjābī. It is called Jaṭkī because in some parts most of its speakers are Jaṭṭs, but the name is not applicable in places where Jaṭṭs are not numerically preponderant. It is called Mūltānī, but this name properly applies only to the form of Lahndā spoken round Multan and the neighborhood. Hindkī and Hindkō, both of which mean 'the language of Hindus', are chiefly used in the trans-Indus districts... The only suitable general names are therefore Western Pañjābī and Lahndā" (Grierson 1903:233-234).

child.alt-names: Shahpur Doabi, Dōābī, Shahpur Doabi Lahnda
child.geography: Doab of the District of Shahpur
child.pub-comments: The term "Dōābī" is not used in the text, but Grierson repeatedly refers to the Lahndā spoken in the Dōāb of the District of Shahpur, which he considers the most "standard" or "typical" form of Southern Lahnda and uses as a benchmark against which to compare other dialects (Grierson 1903:239). There is, however, a "Dōābī" on the Linguistic Survey of India's Lahndā map, which undoubtedly refers to the same thing. I have named this node "Shahpur Dōābī" to differentiate it from the Jullunder Doabi (also simply named "Doabi" on the relevant map) that is a dialect of Pañjābī.

child.pub-comments: Grierson makes it clear that "Jaṭkī" is a generic name used to refer to many different Lahndā dialects (Grierson 1903:233-234). Elsewhere in the Multitree database, the name "Jatki" is tied to the code [skr-jat]; however (in terms of Grierson's classification) that code indicates the "Jaṭkī" spoken within the Mūltānī dialect, which is distinct from this "Jaṭkī", spoken in Jhang and Lyallpur.

child.pub-comments: Grierson uses the name "Mūltānī" to refer to a large dialect group within Southern Lahnda, not just the variety spoken in Multan. He then discusses the variety specifically spoken in Multan, and adds that "the dialect of North Bahawalpur is the same as that of Multan and is locally known as Bahāwalpurī" (Grierson 1903:240). This node is named after the Bahawalpur variety purely because there is no distinctive name for the equivalent Multan variety.

child.pub-comments: According to Grierson, "Sirāikī" was historically considered a dialect of Sindhī in its own right, but the results of the survey lead him to conclude that it is just a form of Vichōlī, though not quite the same as the standard form. He states that the dialect is usually called simply "Sirāikī", but refers to it as "Sirāikī Sindhī" in the text to disambiguate it from the dialect of Lahndā also known as "Sirāikī" (Grierson 1903:9).

child.pub-comments: While Grierson doesn't explicitly name such a group, I have created the node on the basis of the following passage: "The three [Bihārī] dialects fall naturally into two groups, viz., Maithilī and Magahī on the one hand, and Bhojpurī on the other … Magahī, indeed, might very easily be classed as a sub-dialect of Maithilī" (Grierson 1903:3-4).

child.pub-comments: According to Grierson, "Oṛiyā is remarkably free from dialectic variation." He states that Bhatrī is the only "genuine dialet" of Oṛiyā. However, at another point he states that the Oṛiyā spoken in Midnapore is mutually unintelligible with that of other regions, and uses the phrase "Midnapore Oṛiyā" as if naming a dialect (Grierson 1903:369-370), so I have included it in this tree as well.

child.publications: Grierson, George A. 1963. Indo-Aryan Languages, Eastern Group, Linguistic Survey of India, vol. 5. Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass.
child.pub-comments: According to Grierson, "Oṛiyā is remarkably free from dialectic variation." He states that Bhatrī is the only "genuine dialet" of Oṛiyā. However, at another point he states that the Oṛiyā spoken in Midnapore is mutually unintelligible with that of other regions, and uses the phrase "Midnapore Oṛiyā" as if naming a dialect (Grierson 1903:369-370), so I have included it in this tree as well.

child.pub-comments: "Jaipurī" is used as the name for this whole group on Grierson's Rājasthānī dialect map; in the text, he gives Jaipurī as one of the possible names for the group, but generally refers to it as Central-East Rājasthānī, probably to avoid confusion with the specific "Jaipurī" that is a sub-dialect in this group (Grierson 1903:31).

child.pub-comments: "Nīmāḍī is really a form of the Mālvī dialect of Rājasthānī, but it has such marked pecularities of its own that it must be considered separately" (Grierson 1903: 60). "It is by origin a form of Malvi, but is spoken in a rather isolated position amongst a number of non-Aryan hill tribes. It has hence been so affected by the influence of the neighbouring Bhili and Khandesi that it is now a distinct dialect, with marked peculiarities of its own (Grierson 1903: 3).

child.pub-comments: This node is named "Ordinary Pañjābī" for lack of a better name; Grierson states that "Pañjābī has two dialects,- the ordinary idiom of the language, and Ḍōgrā or Ḍōgrī" and refers to "ordinary Pañjābī" at another point in the text also (Grierson 1903:609), but I doubt this is intended as a formal name for the non-Ḍōgrī variety of the language.

child.alt-names: Rechna Doabi, Panjabi of the Rechna Doab and North-east Gujrat
child.pub-comments: Grierson mentions this dialect only briefly, explaining that it is slightly mixed with Lahnda. He does not call it Rechna Doabi, but only Panjabi of the Rechna Doab and North-east Gujrat (1903: 610).

child.publications: Grierson, George A. 1963. Indo-Aryan Languages, Central Group, Linguistic Survey of India, vol. 9. Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass. , Grierson, George A. 1963. child.pub-comments: The term "Doabī" is not used in the text, but Grierson refers several times to the Pañjābī spoken in the Jullunder Doab, and there is a "Doabī" on the Linguistic Survey of India's Pañjābī map, which undoubtedly refers to the same thing. I have named this node "Jullunder Doabī" to differentiate it from the Shahpur Doabi (also simply named "Doabi" on the relevant map) that is a dialect of Lahndā.

child.publications: Grierson, George A. 1963. Indo-Aryan Languages, Central Group, Linguistic Survey of India, vol. 9. Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass.
child.pub-comments: Grierson states that Mājhī "is accepted by natives of India" as the standard dialect of Pañjābī, but that most European scholars regard the Ludhiana dialect as the standard form, because the first Europeans to study and publish grammasr of Pañjābī lived at Ludhiana (Grierson 1903:609). He names the dialect "European Standard Pañjābī" but continues to refer to it as "Ludhiana Pañjābī" or "the Ludhiana Standard".

child.pub-comments: It is unclear whether Grierson's "Western Hindī" is best regarded as a language or as a dialect group. He uses the term "language" to refer to it - for instance, in the title of his map - but also implies that it is a somewhat arbitrarily chosen collection of dialects: "I use 'Eastern Hindī to connote the group of intermediate dialects of which Awadhī is the chief, and 'Western Hindī" to connote the group of dialects of which Braj Bhākhā and Hindōstanī... are the best known" (Grierson 1903:47).

child.alt-names: Braj Bhakha, Braj Bhāshā, Antarbēdī, Antarbedi, Braj Bhasha
child.geography: West Central Doab: district of Agra; States of Bharatpur, Dolpur, and Karauli; eastern Gurgaon; Bulandshahr, Aligarh, Etah, and Mainpuri; Budaon, Bareilly, and Tarai parganas
child.pub-comments: Grierson presents two possible ways of classifying the sub-dialects of Braj Bhākhā - one based on how native speakers usually divide the speech communities, and one based on Grierson's own analysis differing forms of the past participle. I have chosen to primarily reflect the former in this tree, because a) it is used in the Linguistic Survey of India Western Hindi map while the latter is not, and b) Grierson does not name most of the divisions he identifies from his grammatical analysis (Grierson 1903:70).

child.pub-comments: In addition to the Bundēlī sub-dialects included in this tree, Grierson names four "broken dialects" of Bundēlī: Lōdhī, Kōshṭī, Kumbhārī, and Nagpurī (Grierson 1903:88). However, his description of them sounds as though they are simply regions in which code-switching between Bundēlī and another language is common, and they are not included on the Linguistic Survey of India Western Hindi map.

child.pub-comments: Grierson does not really recognize any dialects of Gujarātī. He states that the only real dialectal variation is between the speech of the "educated" and "uneducated", but he does not name those dialects. He also states that native speakers recognize various subdialects but that these don't differ in any significant ways, and does not list these subdialects (Grierson 1903:326).

child.pub-comments: It is unclear whether Grierson's "Eastern Hindī" is best regarded as a language or as a dialect group. He uses the term "language" to refer to it - for instance, in the title of his map - but also implies that it is a somewhat arbitrarily chosen collection of dialects: "I use 'Eastern Hindī to connote the group of intermediate dialects of which Awadhī is the chief, and 'Western Hindī" to connote the group of dialects of which Braj Bhākhā and Hindōstanī... are the best known" (Grierson 1903:47).

child.publications: Grierson, George A. 1963. Indo-Aryan Languages, Mediate Group, Linguistic Survey of India, vol. 6. Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass. , Grierson, George A. 1963. Dialects & subdialects of the Eastern Hindi language, Linguistic Survey of India. Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass.
child.pub-comments: "Chhattīsgaṛhī" and "Khalṭāhī" are distinct regions on the Linguistic Survey of India's Eastern Hindi map, but Grierson explicitly says they are two names for the same language (Grierson 1903:24). Presumably, then, the "Khalṭāhī" area simply indicates the region in which tha language is commonly called "Khalṭāhī".

child.pub-comments: Grierson writes: "Baghēlī differs so little from Awadhī that, were it not popularly recognised as a separate form of speech, I should have certainly classed it as a form of that dialect" (Grierson 1903:1). However, he takes care to distinguish between the two throughout the Survey.

child.pub-comments: Grierson includes a dialect in this group he only refers to as "So-called Bundeli" spoken in Banda. It is not Bundeli, which is a Western Hindi language. For this reason, I've chosen to call the dialect Banda Dialect. It is clear that he considers it a separate dialect (1903: 19).

child.pub-comments: Gõḍwānī is not listed as a dialect in the section that gives an overview of Baghēlī, but rather described in its own section, where Grierson writes: "Gõḍwānī is a form of Eastern Hindi. It is more nearly related to Baghēlī, than to any other dialect of that language (Grierson 1903:158). This statement, together with the fact that Gõḍwānī seems to be included in Baghēlī on the accompanying map, have led me to place Gõḍwānī under Baghēlī in this tree.
